comments.commentBody:
In 1939 the movie Gung Din, based loosely on the Rudyard Kipling poem, starred Cary Grant, Victor McLaglen and Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. and Sam Jaffe as Gunga Din. The story was of colonial Britain conquering northwest India around 1880. Gunga Din was essentially an Indian water boy who sacrificed his life for the British.

From Wiki:

At Din's funeral pyre, the colonel formally inducts Gunga Din as a British corporal and reads the last lines of the Kipling poem over the body:
So I'll meet 'im later on
At the place where 'e is gone --
Where it's always double drill and no canteen;
'E'll be squattin' on the coals
Givin' drink to poor damned souls,
An' I'll get a swig in hell from Gunga Din!
Yes, Din! Din! Din!
You Lazarushian-leather Gunga Din!
Though I've belted you and flayed you,
By the livin' Gawd that made you,
You're a better man than I am, Gunga Din!

The movie is a classic. Sam Jaffe went on to play in many roles but at one time was best known as Dr. David Zorba in the TV series Ben Casey from 1961 to 1965, a series that competed with the TV series Dr. Kildare.

I knew the saying almost immediately and the rest of the puzzle was the challenge. I have always used the expression to compliment a competitor, whether at tennis or another endeavor. One of my favorites!
#45 Skanik: you need good memory, i.e. to be able to count cards :-)

Maybe the CEO's and corporate leaders who decide for their oun financial gain to move financial servicing , factories etc... to countries with poor working/living/ conditions should also be required to live among  their employees  in these countries. I believe that this would return the majority of jobs back to the USA and quickly reduce unemployment and fix the economy.

there should be a limit to the length of any rain delay - either before the game or during the game. so instead of 9pm, make it 2 hours total. (perhaps 3 hours for an afternoon game.)
i went to the game. for any other game i would have gone home, but it was yankees-red sox, so i stayed. and i regret that - not just because the yankees lost. that sort of rain delay on a thursday is totally unacceptable. there is no reasonable way to enjoy the game without friday being completely wasted - and that is not the point of going to a baseball game.
thursday night was a negative event, painful for everyone who was there. they should have canceled the game.

Since November of 2008, the main goal of the Republican party has been to cut federal spending so as to slow down the recovery and keep unemployment high.

They talk about jobs, but low unemployment is the only thing they fear.

Predictable.  Like # 5, with the usual comment about shoot-outs.  What's the difference between that and a no time left field goal?  At lease in a shootout it's two athletes facing each other down.  Kicking a ball between a metal upright, now THAT'S exciting...
Only off with the goals per game stat by a factor of 2
To those at 8, 9, and 10: Judge not, lest thou be judged!

There is of course a very lively debate about the role of productivity in downturns and recoveries. It seems fairly clear that the rate of TFP growth at least is procyclical, declining in downturns and rising in recoveries. (Alexander J. Field, "The Procyclical Behavior of Total Factor Productivity in the United States, 1890–2004," Journal of Economic History 70, No. 2 (Jun 2010): 326-50.) "Real business cycle" (RBC) theorists have argued that indeed TFP movements actually are a major cause of downturns. Having become rather disenchanted with RBC theory in general I tend to find the explanation offered by Field more persuasive: that procyclicality results principally from demand shocks interacting with relatively constant capital services. If this is correct then the gap between capital spending and employment growth would seem to reflectd continuing demand weakness -- anathema of course to neoclassicists. On this account we are likely to see a big gap unless and until there is a big positive demand shock.

I have tried to avoid styrofoam and other plastics, as much as possible, for years. There are paper cups and people should demand them for their take-out coffee an tea, and buy them for their offices.

And, after doing a little quick research, apparently formaldehyde was banned from behing used in home construction materials in 1982, so if your house was built after that, it should be free of this substance.

That all said, it is shameful that our government has allowed these substances to be used in everyday materials that all Americans use. Finding safe alternatives should be on the list of new jobs for Americans.

Tennis and racquetball players who use wooden racquets should know that the pressed wood in the racquet handles is coated with formaldehyde.  My relative, who played tennis daily and was a health nut with no bad habits, died of myeloid leukemia.  So did a colleague who played squash with a wooden-handled racquet.  Anecdotal?  Yes.  But these were otherwise healthy men with no family history of the disease - and I wondered then, and do now, if formaldehyde in the racquets, handled daily, could have caused their disease.

I have been saying for *years* that new houses are toxic and of course, was roundly poo-poohed by my friends and family.

Never mind that as a housepainter that's NOT interested in the horrid end that met more than a few of the 'old-timers' I worked with in the early 80's, I've been educating myself about as many of the building materials as possible.

There's a reason that well over a decade ago, I decided that IF we got to the point of buying a home, it would be one built before 1970.

This is NOT news to those of us paying attention.

The industry groups that have a stake in the outcome should not be allowed to lobby independent government agencies that are investigating adverse health effects. We pay for these government agencies with our tax dollars, precisely because we don't want them to be influenced by the virtually unlimited resources of industry groups.

This article would have been more useful if it suggested more alternative consumer products as was included for wood products such as plywood  & particle board.  By not including an acceptable substitute, for example cellulose instead of fiberglass insulation, the reader is left without the information needed to avoid exposure.  This story was like warning us about a storm coming without any information about how to protect yourself. Interesting but not very useful.

#27 You are probably wrong about the comparative risks to public health of styrofoam cups versus substance abuse. Alcohol, cigarettes, and drug adiction contribute to mortality and morbidity more than the "poisons" you are worried about. This is not to say that removing these substances from products is not a good idea. This is also not an endorsement of the so-called war on drugs.

It is an endorsement of focusing of the most obvious candidates for improving public health and increasing life expectancy.

It's pathetic that the chemical industry would try to defend formaldehyde. But this is only one of thousands of chemicals that we are literally swimming in.  Every day, tons of chemicals are sold and used. Many are bought from our Big Box retailers. After use, they don't disappear, but they mix in our rivers and groundwater into the chemical soup that we are marinating in. No one really knows what the effects of this cocktail will be. The guidelines for EPA water testing were developed 50 years ago, so no one is monitoring. At the moment the chemical corporations have complete freedom to push any poison or genetic engineering onto the market. BEWARE!

Boy, oh boy. What a bunch of frightened lemmings posting on this site. You get more exposure to carcinogens at the gas pump, walking down the road breathing the "fresh air", and soaking in those awful sun-rays! As a group, you overestimate your risks and overreact to announcements about hazardous chemicals. There are dangers in every walk of life. Face the facts, we will all die. In the case of styrene and formaldehyde, most of the risk is borne by people that work in unsafe environments - these need to be addresses. Overuse of cheap wood products containing unsafe levels of formaldehyde can be blamed on people not wanting to pay for real wood. Like many things, the blame can be put on consumers wanting to do things on the cheap as much as manufacturers that make these products. All plastics and polymers are not bad, and too much of anything is not a good idea.

Looking at the comments on this site reveals why such reports are hard fought. The fear and ignorance of facts that they produce is often just as counter productive and damaging as the "evil" products they announce. Calm down, have a cup of coffee and work out safer ways to do things. Stop all the hysteria.
The lobbyists prevent the info about toxins being released, and human life is marginalized, to assure profit margins. What is that?
How many folks have been complaining for years that "Formaldahyde made them sick" and they were dissed as whiners and over-sensitive? Maybe we should have listened to them.

Most New Yorkers know that coffee in styro cups is unacceptable! Look inside the cup and see all those tiny bubbles clinging to the sides. They make the coffee taste like it came out of a tank on a boat.

“All a reasonable person can do is manage their exposure and decrease it to as little as possible. It’s everywhere.”

No, all a reasonable person can do is demand that the government ban these substances so they are no longer "everywhere".

unbelievable, but not surprising, that the manufacturers come back with concerns over what these findings will do to their businesses, in other words the money they make from these dangerous products. No concern that they are responsible for producing products that could be slowly poisoning their customers and maybe more quickly poisoning their employees. No suggestion that maybe they should adapt, as should all businesses, to what the marketplace needs and what is best for the future of civilization, which in this situation is the production of safer and more environmental materials. Other companies already are, I get food in cardboard made from recycled materials, and in bags that are made from vegetable by products.
Their refusal to be innovative and socially responsible is what will doom their companies, not a report that tells the truth about how dangerous their products are.
Wow and machines don't have political affiliations, don't require vacations, sick leave, maternity leave, health care or pensions. Sounds as if the cyborgs have won Arnold.

In a global economy equity prices are not a function of the state of the U.S. economy - they're strictly a referendum on corporate profitability.

And given that the global economy favors the growing markets of developing countries, as well as their inexpensive labor, higher U.S. unemployment, for better or worse, is most likely a harbinger of stronger profits !

I am a high school teacher in rural Arizona. I have taught ninth grade for the past 12 years, and my most challenging classes lately are the ones in which boys far outnumber girls. The behavior issues are greatly magnified. I have talked to our school guidance counselor about this, but we are such a small school that it is difficult to balance classes in terms of gender, etc. I always feel sorry for the girls because most are quiet and don't want to speak up in front of the boys for a variety of reasons. I did have one girl who was an exception. She spoke up too much and too inappropriately. It was difficult to determine if she was trying to be "one of the boys" or if she was trying to appear older and more worldly. I would be concerned if my daughter of any age were one of two girls in a classroom whether it was an elective or a core class.
